sections.name: Angles in UAE Geometry: Classification, Measurement, and Relationships
sections.math_objective: Students will classify angle types (acute, obtuse, right, straight), identify vertical and adjacent angles, and apply angle relationships (linear pair, corresponding angles) while measuring angles using a protractor. They will solve simple angle problems involving the angle addition postulate, with context from UAE geometry and architecture where appropriate.

success_criteria.metric: Number of correctly classified angle types in a 5-item quick-check
Accuracy of angle measurements using protractor in a 5-item task
Group collaboration and role adherence score (rubric 0-4)

teacher.objective: Lead the lesson by introducing angle types and relationships, demonstrate measurement with a protractor, and monitor group work, providing timely feedback and scaffolds.
steps: Present and define angle types (acute, obtuse, right, straight) with UAE-context diagrams (e.g., arch shapes in local architecture) to connect to prior knowledge.
Demonstrate proper protractor technique and model two example measurements with think-aloud reasoning.
Guide students through applying angle relationships (linear pair, vertical angles) and solving for missing angles in provided diagrams; check for misconceptions and record key ideas on the board.

shared.objective: As a group, classify angles in provided diagrams, annotate their types and measures, and justify reasoning using proper terminology on a shared poster.
steps: Agree on classifications for each labeled angle in the diagram and record the type beside each angle.
Compute or measure the required angles as a group, annotate the results, and prepare a brief justification for one angle relationship to present to the class.

1.objective: Student 1 will classify at least 4 of 5 angles and measure at least 4 of 5 angles with a protractor, then explain one angle relationship with justification.
steps: Classify 3 angles in the given diagram and label each with its type.
Measure 2 angles with the protractor, record measurements, and compare with peers.

2.objective: Student 2 will classify the remaining angles, measure at least 3 angles, and contribute one justification for an angle relationship in the group notes.
steps: Classify the remaining angles in the diagram and verify consistency with Student 1.
Measure 2-3 angles and provide a brief justification for one angle relationship; contribute to the group poster.
